ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Several hours per week when there was a paper, homework or exam
3hr/week average
1 hour/week on average.

Outside the class, I would spend probably around 2-3 hours worth of studying. In the case there was a paper due, that would usually add about 6-8 hours more in the week it was due, which I think was fair.
Little to no work required during weeks without an assignment. Two easy math sets that take very little time, two papers which require a few hours of background reading to write.
approximately 1.5 hours.
Depending on the week, I would say average 5 hours? Though two weeks before the midterm and final I would say on average at least 15 hours (there is a lot of material).
8-10 hours

Depends on the week, for papers and tests, quite a long time, if someone spent just an hour or two every week going over the lectures well, they'll understand the concepts, as the class is very well taught, I feel.
not much. crammed a lot for the exams. spent decent amount of time on the papers.
5 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The instructor is amazing. The material is really interesting if you are a health care provider or interested in environmental health. Otherwise, I think it would be sort of technical for people. There is very little work outside of class except for the two papers and studying for the (very fair) midterm and final.
Great!

Having a background in this area, I found the course to be really amazing. It came highly recommended from other PH students, and Dr. Borak really lived up to expectation. The design of the course content really facilitates the learning- the first half covers concepts, vocabulary and mechanisms (with many anecdotal tie-ins for medicine and science) and then the second half covers specific areas- focusing on specific toxicants and the policy implications. I especially liked the guest lecturer from DEP (Brad Robinson) who gave an excellent talk on how toxicology fits into the pesticide regulation at the DEP.

Strengths: good introduction to tox that really emphasizes the mechanisms and principles as opposed to pure memorization;Weakness: as I was studying for the final, I found inconsistencies or unexplained information in the lecture slides. sometimes it seemed we were expected to understand chemistry that we had not been taught.
I thought the final was incredibly hard, especially in relation to the midterm. There needs to be a clearer way to pick out the important concepts out of the hundreds of slides given to students.
Toxicology was one of my favorite classes. Good, fairly well organized lectures and useful assignments.
Very informative and diverse subject matter.

Strengths:Instructors, their expertise, their academic and real-world knowledge, and the oh-so-current materials that they provide.Weaknesses: Beware! Don't let the lack of assignments in the first 5 weeks keep you from reading the Casarett and Doull's. Dig in and follow along aggressively, or you'll be sorry when the assignments and midterm comes.
The strengths of the course were the minimal workload and the lectures, themselves, which were extremely engaging, interesting, and informational.
Strengths: explain the basic concepts of toxicology, how to do a toxicology analysis, uses specific examples to illustrate basic concepts.Weakness: too dense...

I thoroughly enjoyed the course. Out of the intro-level courses that I took that are part of the core MPH 1st year curriculum, I would have to say that Tox was the course which I took the most away from. It was thematic, had real-world applicability and Borak is a charasmastic professor. I would improve upon the course by probably spending a little less time on the case study examples (TCE, Hg, Percholorate) - note, i wouldn't eliminate them, just a little less time, and do more mechanistic work.

This is a great course as an introduction to the concepts and vocabulary of toxicology. The course helps students develop an understanding of the dose-response relationship and the fundamentals of exposure to toxic compounds, which are practical skills for many fields in public health.

The first half of this course is a great introduction to toxicology. The course is necessarily broad, given the wide variety of student backgrounds. If you were a biochem major in college, this might seem pretty basic, but otherwise it's a manageable balance between general concepts and details. The second half of the course focuses on applying toxicology principles to specific chemicals. I personally found this section of the class less satisfying.
The class is really great, but very difficult. I think there should be no problem for at least the final to be open notes...we are required to memorize a great deal of information and then apply it.

final questions were not indicative of major concepts we covered. for example, first and second half of the semester was dedicated to 1st and 2nd order of elimination but the final asked for zero order elimination, a concept we did not cover. The mid-term was fair and asked directly on topics we discussed in depth.
This was a pretty interesting course, definately outside my comfort zone academically, but I was still able to get something out of it.
first half was great but final half with case studies was confusing and failed to complement the knowledge gained in the first half

The course disappointed me. I was hoping for something with more substance, and it ended up being a basic review of a lot of general chemistry, biochemistry and organic chemistry material from undergrad. 60% of the semester's lectures were spent "getting everyone on the same page" with all this background information. I do not know why this class is offered to everyone, including those students without any biology or chemistry background because it is so focused on these subjects.Also, I found the two written assignments lacked direction and the expectations were not clear.

The course was great; I've never taken a toxicology course before so this was a terrific introduction. Both Prof. Borak and Cheryl know their fields extremely well. Though I wouldn't mind if there were more homeworks/if they counted for a grade. Also it bothered me that I didn't know how my grade was going to be calculated...
One of my favorite courses. The professor was engaging, the assignments and exams were fair.

Course can be better structured and made less rigorous.A lot of material that turned out not to be needed for the course was given.Tons of lecture slides were given and then innocuous questions were asked on the slides.

Great, Prof. Borak is a very engaging speaker, I found myself getting excited to come to class simply to hear the man speak, and Cheryl's superb as well.The class had two papers, both of which should be well-researched, so don't put them off, and be sure to communicate with Cheryl and Prof. Borak, they both are very eager to help and genuinely great people outside of class as well.There were two tests, which were kind of hit and miss, in terms of what you studied, I suppose the idea being that you study it all well. Certain slides are disproportionately used for testing info more than others, and if you don't realize which ones these are, you find yourself studying to rote dozens of slides that won't show up on the test at all. Of course this fact reminds me of how much I learned in this course, and how much material there was. It is a really great class, not terrible with work in the beginning, but very end of semester heavy, so watch for that. Don't let anything I wrote here discourage you from taking the class however, for me, the class was a great opportunity to learn so much in a fascinating subject that gets far too little airtime in other classes. Wonderfully taught by teachers that care (and know, a lot), and a solid class.
it's okay for those who are really interested in the course. not so good for those who are just exploring. I don't feel like I learned many new things and I didn't enjoy being in class.
I wish there were more toxicology courses offered. Especially if it was by this instructor.
This was a very interesting course to take. The instructor tries to provide a brief overview of a very broad field.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak was enthusiastic, articular, and totally compelling to listen to. He told great anecdotes and made the class really interesting and fun. He is s stickler for detail, but this also means that he expects the best from everyone. I have an incredible amount of respect for him and also think he was quite entertaining.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Great speaker!

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Excellent lecturer. I like the fact that he has an MD and can go into detail about how many of the concepts apply to medicine. Very enthusiastic, and I really can't think of any way to improve his teaching.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Good lecturer

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak could probably read from a phone book and find a way to make it interesting. He is an outstanding lecturer. Of equal importance was his interest in leaving students of the course with practical applications and appreciations for the material as opposed to testing rote memorization.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Extremely interesting lecturer. Could make anything seem interesting! Pleasure to be in his class.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak is a very engaging lecturer. He is good at explaining difficult concepts and always has entertaining examples. After a couple lectures you will not be surprised to learn that he consults for industry clients - he has a somewhat conservative view on regulation, precaution, and new toxicology findings in general.Cheryl Fields, who works for Dr. Borak's consulting firm, also gives a good number of the lectures. Cheryl is very nice and not a bad lecturer, but she clearly does not have the same level of expertise as Dr. Borak.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Humorous, engaging, and commanding. Maintains your interest throughout class.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr Borak is a faculty leader who cares immensely about the science, the theory, and the field in which he lectures, writes, and operates a leading toxicology consultancy. Moreover, he is a teacher who cares immensely about the students' opportunities to get a foundation in toxicology and in toxicological/ecological risk assessment.Masterfully weaves a compelling, science-based, policy-laden narrative out of complex and subtle science -- and teaches you toxicology, so that you leave the class feeling prepared to think through the mechanisms of toxicology in any given circumstance.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak was the reason I initially chose to take the course (ultimately, the reason for my enjoying the course become toxicology, itself; but this was, of course, a product of Dr. Borak and his engaging method of teaching the material).
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  I enjoyed Prof. Borak's animated lecture, his stories and his passion for toxicology. He makes toxicology fun.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  He made this course so interesting,
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Prof Borak was great, I always enjoyed his lectures. He was excellent at making sure we understood the big picture.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  The instructor is a very dynamic and charismatic lecturer, which made classes both interesting and enjoyable. The instructor did a good job organizing the course, presenting the fundamentals during the first half and then applying these concepts to specific examples.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Very knowledgeable and a great lecturer.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak is a good lecturer, albeit a bit self-satisfied. He explains things clearly, but I didn't find him to be terribly approachable. Chery's lectures seemed to be all over the place, and my notes from her lectures in class did not match the material in the slides. It was hard to understand the main points, but easy to prepare for the exams because they came primarily from the slides.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak does a great job of explaining complex ideas in a simplified manner. However, there seems to be a bit of an attitude that this stuff is just easy and it's not a difficult class. THere is a great amount of information we are to retain. It IS difficult.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Engaging!
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  funny guy
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Prof. Borak is a great lecturer, he's serious in helping us learn.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak is one of my favorite instructors... very good at engaging the class

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr Borak is a good instructor but I feel there was a gap in passing the knowledge across to the students.Classes were too complicated and could have been simplified.Cheryl Fields: Good instructor although not very confident when addressing the class.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Great, Prof. Borak is a very engaging speaker, I found myself getting excited to come to class simply to hear the man speak. Cheryl's manner of treating differents subjects had me excited for her presentations as well. Both are very generous with their time, dispite the work they do. Each of them really reaches out to the students, especially if you don't understand or do badly. Both of them are very knowledgeable and are easily able to synthesize from their thoughts simple, yet fitting explenations of the subject matter. An hour with either of them is worth a much longer time reading a text, simply due to their ability to state facts and summarize general trends and concepts: a rarity in teachers I've run into thus far in my academic career. Both of them should keep up the good work.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  wasn't there half the time. good lecturer. not very cohesive material.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak is one of the best instructors I have ever had. He is a motivated professor. He has a great understanding of the students needs and has a strong desire to meet these needs.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Very interesting and vibrant. Keeps students paying attention even when it seems difficult to do so.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If you are interested in how different compounds do damage to the human body (like how carcinogens cause cancer on a cellular level) this is the course for you. It is very detail-oriented and looks at mechanisms of action and concepts of pharmacology. It is fascinating for those who find these topics fascinating, which I happen to.
Great

The course covers the basic concepts of toxicology, focusing on exposures, ADME and mechanisms of toxicity. A lot of the material is very molecular so having a background in molecular or cell biology is a great help. The instructor is one of the best I have had as a teacher, and while not relevant to everyone's interest/future direction, it gives a good idea of how environmental factors can become public health concerns. There is also significant connection with policy and regulation.
A good option for the EHS requirement if you have had some chemistry
I would recommend it over other environmental classes, as it is interesting, but very difficult subject matter.

The first half of the course covers the basic principles of toxicology and the second half is focused on case studies as applications of these principles. There are 2 quick math sets, 2 short writing assignments, a midterm, and a final exam. Reading is not necessary, but the text book is very good. If you get the big version of the book you will never have time to sit down and actually read the chapters, but it makes for an excellent reference book.
A very basic introduction to the subject matter. A more technical class could be offered through the medical school.
Toxicology is a loadstone for any fundamental research in medical science,environmental science, and public health.Take this course.

A great course to gain a basic understanding of toxicology and it relates to you on a daily basis. I would definitely recommend it to another student because of the instructor, the interesting material (particularly if you enjoy biochemistry), and the course load.
Yes. Interesting course..

This course is about the mechanisms by which toxins and toxicants are absorbed, metabolized and excreted from the body. Yes, I would 100% recommend the course to another student, given that I truly learned and retained a great deal. The professor was engaging and funny, easy to learn from.

This course provides a useful overview of the fundamental concepts of toxicology. I would recommend this course, as it gives students a good framework for further exploration and understanding of toxicology.

The first half of this course is a great introduction to toxicology. The course is necessarily broad, given the wide variety of student backgrounds. If you were a biochem major in college, this might seem pretty basic, but otherwise it's a manageable balance between general concepts and details. The second half of the course focuses on applying toxicology principles to specific chemicals. I personally found this section of the class less satisfying.
This class has a lot ofvaluable information. However it is very difficult, and I would only recommend it to someone who has an interest in the subject.
Toxicology is a rough ride if you aren't a chemistry person. I wish I had been warned...
Not a great course. If you have experience in biochemistry, you won't gain too much from this course.
I really enjoyed the course, though I must admit it was the toughest of my course schedule this semester.

Good course although i feel that introduction to toxicology can be better structured.Two problem sets were assigned and we were not told until completing the problem sets that they would not be included in our final grades.Innocuous and obscure questions were asked after studying tons of material.The grading for the papers and exams was very tough and not well explained.Recommended only if you love toxicology/environmental health sciences with a passion.

Great, Prof. Borak is a very engaging speaker, I found myself getting excited to come to class simply to hear the man speak, and Cheryl's superb as well.The class had two papers, both of which should be well-researched, so don't put them off, and be sure to communicate with Cheryl and Prof. Borak, they both are very eager to help and genuinely great people outside of class as well.There were two tests, which were kind of hit and miss, in terms of what you studied, I suppose the idea being that you study it all well. Certain slides are disproportionately used for testing info more than others, and if you don't realize which ones these are, you find yourself studying to rote dozens of slides that won't show up on the test at all. Of course this fact reminds me of how much I learned in this course, and how much material there was. It is a really great class, not terrible with work in the beginning, but very end of semester heavy, so watch for that. Don't let anything I wrote here discourage you from taking the class however, for me, the class was a great opportunity to learn so much in a fascinating subject that gets far too little airtime in other classes. Wonderfully taught by teachers that care (and know, a lot), and a solid class.

Not easy, but not super difficult either. Lectures aren't that great. TONS of memorization and perhaps most interesting for really sciencey folks. You may want to take environmental for the requirement if you don't mind busy work but don'twant to use too much brain energy.
Toxicology is a great course. It is a very basic level class and your time is well spent.
